#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Patent a Recipe
#Text=Did you invent a recipe that you 're certain has never been tasted by the world before ?
#Text=You might have a uniquely delicious concoction on your hands , but in order to patent it , your recipe must be considered novel , non-obvious and useful .
#Text=Home cooks and chefs have been mixing ingredients for thousands of years , so coming up with something completely new is n't easy .
#Text=If your recipe does n't meet these qualifications , there are other legal protections you can put in place to claim it as your own .
#Text=Read on to learn more about how to patent a recipe .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Figuring Out if Your Recipe is Patentable
#Text=Understand what makes something patentable .

#Text=Section 35 USC ยง 101 on patent law states that " Whoever invents or discovers any new and useful process , machine , manufacture , or composition of matter , or any new and useful improvement thereof , may obtain a patent therefor , subject to the conditions and requirements of this title . "
#Text=Recipes can fall into this category in two different ways , since they are always useful , they may involve a new process or technique , and they include a composition of matter .
#Text=All of this is to say that recipes are indeed possible to patent as long as they meet the other requirements .
#Text=Determine if your recipe is novel .
#Text=In legal terminology , " novel " refers to something that did not previous exist .
#Text=This is where things get tricky when it comes to patenting recipes .
#Text=It 's very difficult to determine whether a particular mix of ingredients has been whipped up in someone 's kitchen before .
#Text=There are a few forms of research you should undertake in order to see if your recipe is novel enough to patent .
#Text=Search the United States Patent and Trademark Office database to see if your recipe has already been patented .
#Text=Search cookbooks and the Internet for your recipe .

#Text=If you find the recipe in either location you may be ineligible for a patent because of an existing patent or the recipe will be considered already " disclosed " if it has been published elsewhere .
#Text=If you cannot find an exact replication of the recipe , you can proceed to determining whether your recipe meets the other qualifications .
#Text=Determine if your recipe is non-obvious .
#Text=If your recipe involves a technique or combination of ingredients that leads to unique , non-obvious results , it may be patentable .
#Text=However , if your recipe is something that could easily be thought up by someone else , or involves techniques that lead to predictable results , it 's probably not patentable .
#Text=Since most recipes invented by home cooks do n't lead to results that would surprise a seasoned cook , they usually are n't patentable .
#Text=Food companies are more likely to create recipes that are patentable , because they are able to use experimental processes and ingredients that lead to non-obvious results .
#Text=For example , a patentable recipe might be one that uses a new technique to give it a surprisingly long shelf life .
#Text=Simply adding a unique ingredient to a recipe is n't non-obvious enough to make it patentable .
#Text=For example , an experimental home cook might decide to add cinnamon to a meatloaf recipe .
#Text=Though the results might be surprisingly delicious , most home chefs could predict the flavor change that the addition of cinnamon would bring about .
#Text=Applying for a Patent
#Text=Decide what kind of patent you need .
#Text=There are several different kinds of patents available and a recipe could fall into more than one category of patents .
#Text=The Utility Patent protects new inventions that have a useful application .
#Text=This covers new methods , processes , machines , manufactured items , devices or chemical compounds or any new improvements to any of these .
#Text=Most recipes would fall under the Utility Patent category .
#Text=The product shape or packaging may also be susceptible to protection under a design patent .
#Text=In this case you could apply for one of those as well .
#Text=Figure out where you need patent protection .
#Text=Patents can be filed either in the United States or in other countries .
#Text=If you feel that your recipe requires international protection , then you should apply for a patent in countries where you want patent protection .
#Text=The European Union offers a " European Patent Office " that facilitates patent applications for countries within the EU .

column1: #Text=Work with an attorney to file your paperwork .
#Text=There are patent lawyers who specialize in filing the necessary paperwork with the United States Patent and Trademark Office .

#Text=While you 're certainly allowed to submit your own paperwork , the patent office recommends you hire a lawyer at this point to handle the flow of paperwork and make sure you submit all the required materials .
#Text=Regardless of who does the actual filing , the papers are then submitted electronically to the patent office .
#Text=The application cover sheet and list of required attachments can be obtained from the United States Patent and Trademark Office website , at uspto . gov .
#Text=The patent application should be filed either online or via regular mail ( note that filing online will allow you to avoid the $ 400 filing fee and speed up the process considerably ) .
#Text=Wait for your application to be approved or rejected .
#Text=The US patent office will consider your paperwork and make a determination if your recipe is eligible for a patent .
#Text=If you 're approved , the patent office will contact you .
#Text=After you pay an issue and publication fee , your patent will be granted .
#Text=The vast majority of patent applications are routinely rejected .
#Text=You should not take it personally .
#Text=Examiners are required to enforce the rules diligently and it often works out to your advantage , resulting in a more valuable patent .
#Text=If your application is rejected you have an opportunity to argue or to amend ( narrow ) the claims or to appeal the examiners ' final decision .
#Text=This often takes several years and thousands of dollars in filing fees and attorneys ' fees .
#Text=If your application is finally rejected and you abandon it , and you still want to protect your recipe , you can do so by protecting it as a trade secret .
#Text=Those who know the secret will be required to sign a non-disclosure agreement , and in this way you can prevent your recipe from getting leaked .
